questions.text: The plain x-ray shows a particular change in ribs. This is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The x-ray depicts the inferior rib notching, which is a finding associated with coarctation of the aorta.

Coarctation of the aorta is the narrowing/constriction of the aorta most commonly occurring at origin of ductus arteriosis. It can also be seen preductal or post ductal and is associated with Turner syndrome.

Preductal or infantile type has severe coarctation become symptomatic as soon as the duct begins to close. Differential cyanosis and radial-femoral delay are classic signs.

Adult or juxta ductal is usually mild and goes unnoticed until adolescence. They present as weakness, pain or claudication in legs after exercise, hypertension in the upper extremities with weak pulses and hypotension in the lower extremities.

Roesler sign-Notching of the inferior margin of the ribs(4th-8th) from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels is common by late childhood. 

A figure of 3 sign (Reverse 3) is a contour abnormality of the aorta as shown below.

Rib notching refers to the deformation of the superior or inferior surface of the rib. Osteogenesis imperfecta, rheumatoid arthritis and hyperparathyroidism are associated with superior rib notching.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. Identify the sign and the type of twin gestation it indicates.
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

The "T sign" seen in sonographic images signifies a monochorionic twin pregnancy, where there is a lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium since birth. A contrast enema shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 3-day-old presenting with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium, with a contrast enema showing microcolon (entire colon is small in calibre) is suggestive of meconium ileus.

Cystic fibrosis is the most common cause of meconium ileus. In cystic fibrosis, the malfunctioning ATP-gated chloride channels result in the formation of dense and thick meconium. This becomes lodged in the terminal ileum, leading to a blockage in the distal part of the intestine.

Clinical features in a newborn include the inability to pass meconium within the initial 24-48 hours after birth, accompanied by indicators of small bowel obstruction. These signs include bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. 

Abdominal X-ray in meconium ileus reveals dilated small bowel loops and a soap-bubble appearance in the right iliac fossa, caused by the combination of meconium and gas. Contrast enema examination shows an empty microcolon.

Other options: 

Option A: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a rapidly progressive disease that causes extensive bowel necrosis, infection, and perforation in newborns. Pneumatosis intestinalis (shown below) is a radiographic finding that appears as train-track lucency within the bowel wall due to bacterial gas production. Other findings may include portal vein gas and pneumoperitoneum.


Option B: Intussusception is a common cause of intestinal obstruction in pediatric patients due to the telescoping of bowel into an adjacent segment. It may arise due to lead points such as an inflamed Peyer’s patch, Meckel’s diverticulum, intestinal polyp, or an inflamed appendix. Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign/bull's eye sign (as shown below).


Option D: Duodenal atresia is caused by the failure of vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is commonly seen in newborns with Down’s syndrome. Babies usually present with bilious vomiting immediately after birth. A plain X-ray abdomen reveals two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum called the double bubble sign (as shown below).

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presents with excessive bleeding during her menstrual cycles for the last year. Laboratory evaluation reveals iron deficiency anemia. Abdominal examination reveals an enlarged uterus corresponding to 14 weeks with an irregular contour.  Her ultrasound is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with menorrhagia, iron deficiency anemia, and the irregular, enlarged uterus is uterine leiomyoma.

The image shows an ultrasound with a large fibroid within the uterine cavity. 

Leiomyoma or fibroid uterus are slow-growing, benign tumors of the uterus that affect women of reproductive age. They occur due to smooth muscle proliferation in response to estrogen and progesterone produced by the body. 

Conditions with hormone excess such as reproductive age group, hyperestrogenism, pregnancy, and oral contraceptives are associated with increased growth of fibroids. 

Fibroids are formed in the intramural (interstitial), submucous, and subserous parts of the uterus. They can also form in the extrauterine structures such as round ligament, uterosacral ligament, vagina, and vulva. 

Patients usually present with menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, infertility, recurrent abortions, pain, pressure symptoms, abdominal mass, and vaginal discharge. However, many women are asymptomatic. 

Fibroids can undergo secondary changes such as atrophy, calcareous degeneration, and red degeneration. 

Other options: 

Option A - Endometrial carcinoma is unlikely to cause irregular uterine contour. In addition, it usually occurs in older women and presents as post-menopausal bleeding. 

Option B - Pregnant uterus would also be enlarged, but it would be soft, and round. She would also have a history of amenorrhea. In addition, an ultrasound will reveal the fetal anatomy. 

Option D - Uterine adenomyosis is a condition seen frequently in elderly women (Age > 40 years), which is characterized by endometrial islands in the wall of the uterus. It is similar in presentation to fibroids except that in adenomyosis, the uterus would be uniformly enlarged and would not be more than 12 to 14 weeks gestation in size. 

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The contrast radiograph given above is that of barium follow-through.

It is useful in visualising small bowel pathology. It is performed following a barium meal examination of the oesophagus, stomach, and duodenum. It is inferior to enteroclysis where contrast is administered through NG tube. It is also used to evaluate the function of the small bowel.

Barium meal examines the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

Preparations and uses of Barium sulfate as a contrast in GI imaging:

  • Ba swallow uses barium paste (for esophagus).
  • Ba meal - 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum).
  • Ba meal follow through - 50% BaSO4 (for small bowel).
  • Ba enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel).
  • For Single contrast films, barium alone is used. Double-contrast films require air and barium which is better for a small mucosal lesion.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheoesophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Perforation peritonitis and esophageal perforation: Iohexol is used.

The above radiograph shows barium meal. 

Barium enema: contrast is administered through a rectal tube and series of radiographs are obtained. It still remains the investigation of choice to visualize fine mucosal detail and also a very good technique for demonstration of general colonic configuration and caliber. The above radiograph is double-contrast barium enema with normal large bowel structure.

This is a recent NEET pattern question and a must know topic.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text:
A woman presents to you with a feeling of heaviness of her head, swelling on the forehead, and dull headache throughout the day. On investigating further, her serum ALP levels are raised and the following radiographic changes are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?

ALP- Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of heaviness of head, swelling on the forehead, dull headache throughout the day, raised serum ALP levels, and the radiograph showing Tam o' Shanter sign are suggestive of Paget's disease.

Paget's bone disease (PBD) is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity. It is usually asymptomatic but can present with a dull aching pain unless the disease is severe. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma. Serum ALP levels may be raised or maybe normal. Treatment is done using intravenous zoledronate given as a single infusion of 4-5 mg.

Radiographic features: 

  • The early phase features the osteolytic (lucent) region which is later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement.
  • Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. 
  • Osteoporosis circumscripta is seen as a large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance  is seen as a mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion of the skull
  • Tam o'Shanter sign is frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones.
  • Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 

The image below shows the cotton-wool appearance of the skull seen in Paget's disease:

The image below shows Tam O Shanter hat sign in skull radiograph:

The arrow mark in the image given below depicts the 'blade of grass'/Flame shaped lesion.

The image given below depicts a picture-frame appearance seen in vertebral bodies.

The image given below depicts the Ivory vertebra sign.

Other options:

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism is characterised by increased circulating parathyroid hormone levels. There is osteoclastic hyperactivity resulting in hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis and chondrocalcinosis. Typical features in radiology include subperiosteal cortical resorption and osteoporosis. 

Option C: Multiple myeloma is the most common primary malignancy occurring in the bone and is characterised by the presence of punched-out osteolytic lesions resulting in a pepper pot appearance of the axial skeleton.

Option D: Osteomyelitis refers to the infection of the bone more commonly starting in the trabeculae. Radiographic features include periosteal new bone formation around the second week of infection which later progresses to periosteal thickening. 

Related Pearl: Bone scan findings

Causes of a hot spot

Causes of a cold spot

Osteomyelitis

Bone tumors and metastases

Fibrous dysplasia

Trauma (fracture healing)

Avascular necrosis

Perthes disease

Paget’s disease

Hyperparathyroidism

Multiple myeloma

Fibrous cortical defect

Pseudoarthrosis

Related Pearl: Biochemical parameters in metabolic bone diseases

Metabolic bone disease

 Calcium PTH Phosphate ALP

Rickets / Osteomalacia

  ↓/N    ↑         ↓    ↑

Primary

hyperparathyroidism

      ↑    ↑        ↓  ↑

Secondary

hyperparathyroidism

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A child presented with swelling of the wrist joint. She also had perifollicular hemorrhages and ecchymosis around hair follicles. Bleeding gums were seen on examination. An x-ray of her wrist is shown below. Identify the marked sign.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scurvy and the sign marked by the arrow is Wimberger's sign. It is a ring-shaped outline of the epiphysis.

Dietary deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy. It is common between 6 and 9 months of age. Defective osteoid production by osteoblasts with reduced endochondral bone ossification is likely to be the cause of the condition.

Clinical features include bleeding into the skin which includes petechiae, ecchymosis, perifollicular hemorrhages, bleeding into joints, and bleeding gums which are mainly due to the impaired formation of connective tissue.

Radiological features:

  • Trummerfeld zone

  • Frankel's line - an increased density at the metaphyseal ends (Option D)

  • Pelcan's spur - seen in the metaphysis and is prone to fracture (Option B), and

  • Wimberger's sign - a pencil-shaped outline seen in the epiphysis. (Option A).

Treatment includes supplementation of vitamin C (200 mg/day).

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important differences between vitamin D and vitamin C deficiencies

 
Vitamin D     deficiency  
Vitamin C     deficiency
Pathology Poor mineralization of bone Poor osteoid          formation
Clinical features

No/less irritability

Rachitic rosary (nodularity at the costochondral junction)

Irritability is predominant

Scorbutic rosary (angular & sharp costochondral junction)
Radiological features

Cupping 

Fraying

Splaying

White line of Frankel

Pelkan spur

Wimberger ring sign

Subperiosteal hemorrhage

Note: Irritability in scurvy is due to hampered neurotransmitter production (conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine and tryptophan to serotonin requires vitamin C).

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is Hurler's syndrome.

As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Other options:

Option A- Tay-Sachs disease is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase-A resulting in the excess storage of GM2 ganglioside within the lysosomes of cells. The clinical features include developmental delay, intellectual impairment, seizures, and breathing difficulty.

The CT image shows macrocephaly and reduced attenuation of the cerebral white matter. MRI can delineate deep white matter demyelination, and indicate calcification in thalami on T2 weighted sequences.

Option C- Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance due to the deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of a glycolipid (glucocerebroside) within the lysosomes of macrophages.

The clinical features include bone pain, pathological fractures, bone crises hepatosplenomegaly, and hematological disturbances.

The radiological features of the skeletal involvement include osteopenia, osteonecrosis, fractures (pathological), Erlenmeyer flask deformity, and H-shaped vertebra.

Option D- Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 2 resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

The clinical features include abnormal facies characterized by the prominent forehead, flattened nasal bridge, coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, hepatosplenomegaly.

These patients lack clouding of the cornea.

The radiological features include thickened calvaria, enlargement of the skull, broad clavicle and ribs, thoracolumbar kyphosis, hip dysplasia, and genu valgum deformity.

Related Pearl: MPS and Their Respective Enzyme Deficiencies

Disease MPS Enzyme defective GAGs affected Symptoms

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the computed tomography (CT) image provided below?
questions.solution:
The given image is a CT pulmonary angiography showing a pulmonary (saddle) embolism.

CT pulmonary angiography using multi-detector CT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. 

An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus. Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses. Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature.

Depending on the size of the embolus, it can occlude the main pulmonary artery; straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus); or pass out into the smaller, branching arteries.

The below image shows a CT thorax of saddle embolism.

Other options

Option A- Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as an increase in vascular resistance of the pulmonary circulation involving a combination of vasoconstriction and remodeling of small vessels. Hemodynamically, it is defined as a systolic pulmonary artery pressure of more than 35 mmHg or a mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) >20 mmHg

A diameter of the main pulmonary artery at the level of its bifurcation of more than 29 mm helps in the diagnosis of PH.

Option B- Thoracic aortic aneurysm occurs due to the intrinsic weakness of the aortic wall and they rarely manifest with symptoms. A CECT scan is the most widely used for diagnosis and it assesses the size, extent, and location of the aneurysm.

The below image shows a CT scan of a ruptured thoracic aortic aneurysm. The black arrow is the aorta and the white arrow is blood in the thorax.

Option D- The mural thrombus of the aorta is the thrombus attached to the wall of an aorta. They occur in the normal or minimally atherosclerotic vessel. The modality for diagnosis of mural thrombi is CT or MRI angiography.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A newborn baby presented to the pediatrician with respiratory distress.  On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. The baby was born via normal vaginal delivery at term and antenatal visits were not done regularly. An X-ray of the infant is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: For small defects a porous polytetrafluoroethylene patch can be used
Extra corporeal membranous oxygenation is contraindicated
Conventional mechanical ventilation is used for managing respiratory failure
Bag and mask ventilation should be used in the initial management

questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with a mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and conventional mechanical ventilation is the main strategy used to support respiratory failure in infants with CDH.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia.  Bochdalek hernia is the most common variant.

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Diaphragmatic eventration
  • Cystic adenomatoid malformation
  • Bronchogenic cyst
  • Cystic teratoma

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

During surgery, the viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fi-O2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, the characteristic appearance marked by arrows, is seen as shown in the MRI image below
questions.solution:
The above image shows ovoid lesions with their long axis perpendicular to the ventricular surface called Dawson fingers (white arrows) which are characteristically seen in multiple sclerosis.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is considered to be autoimmune in origin and is the most common demyelinating disease.

MRI is the study of choice in imaging multiple sclerosis because of its greater sensitivity than computed tomography in demonstrating plaques, both in the brain and spinal cord.

questions.text: A 48-year-old premenopausal woman complained of heavy menstrual bleeding and bleeding between her cycles. The patient was in good health, with no other complaints. No significant past history. She was referred for a pelvic ultrasound which revealed a 12 x 11mm mass within the endometrial cavity surrounded by free fluid. Doppler US established internal vascularity via a single feeder vessel. Which among the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical case described along with visualization of a feeding vessel on ultrasonography is characteristic of an endometrial polyp, and oral contraceptive pills are not a risk factor.

Risk factors for development of endometrial polyps include:

  • Increasing age
  • Obesity
  • Tamoxifen use 
  • Some studies suggest an association with hormone replacement therapy

Oral contraceptive pills appear to be protective. For women taking tamoxifen, the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) was investigated and shown to lower endometrial polyp formation rates.

Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.

Benign endometrial polyps commonly occur at all ages, with their greatest prevalence after age 50. They are a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding. Women with polyps may present with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging.

On transvaginal sonography, endometrial polyps may appear as a nonspecific area of endometrial thickening or a round or elongated hyperechoic focal mass within the endometrial cavity. Some polyps may contain cystic spaces corresponding to dilated endometrial glands.  On color or power Doppler, endometrial polyps typically have only one arterial feeding vessel.

Treatment is by hysteroscopic polypectomy for symptomatic women or women with risk factors for malignant transformation. For asymptomatic women without risk factors, conservative management with regular monitoring can be done.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady with recent-onset, progressive dementia presents with myoclonus. The brain imaging findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

The imaging studies are diffusion-weighted imaging and T2-weighted-fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (T2-FLAIR) imaging. The findings of cortical ribboning and basal ganglia hyperintensity on the two abovementioned MRI modalities have a high sensitivity and specificity. This has diminished the need for brain biopsy in patients with suspected CJD.

CJD is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia and is usually fatal within 1 year of the onset of symptoms.

Symptoms are almost always rapidly progressive, and the clinical presentation includes the following:

  • Myoclonus
  • Higher cortical deficits
  • Psychiatric manifestations - depression, psychosis, and visual hallucinations
  • Profound dementia - memory loss, impaired judgment, intellectual decline
  • Visual impairment or cerebellar gait and coordination deficits in a few patients
  • Nonspecific prodromal symptoms - fatigue, sleep disturbance, weight, loss, headache, anxiety, vertigo, malaise, and ill-defined pain 
  • Extrapyramidal dysfunction - rigidity, masklike facies, choreoathetoid movements;
  • Seizures
  • Hypoesthesia
  • Supranuclear gaze palsy, optic atrophy

EEG shows repetitive, high-voltage, triphasic, and polyphasic sharp discharges in advanced cases. CSF analysis shows a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. Brain biopsy shows the presence of prion protein scrapie (PrPSc).

Management is mainly supportive. 

Other options:

Option A: Dementia with Lewy bodies is the most common disorder to be mistaken for CJD. It has a subacute presentation with delirium, myoclonus, and extrapyramidal features. The absence of abnormalities on diffusion-weighted and T2-FLAIR MRI will almost always distinguish most dementias from CJD.

Option B: MRI in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy reveals multifocal asymmetric, coalescing white matter lesions located in the periventricular region, in the centrum semiovale, parietal-occipital region, and in the cerebellum. These lesions show an increased signal on T2 and FLAIR. 

Option C: MRI in subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is usually normal in the early stages. Increased T2 signaling in the white matter of the brain is seen as the disease progresses.

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with easy fatiguability and backache. He has had recurrent infections in the past 3 months. Reports showed hypercalcemia. His skull x-ray is  below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. The given radiograph represents the multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance, which is seen in multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. The incidence of multiple myeloma increases with age, and it is more commonly seen in males than in females.

Bone pain is the most common symptom and is due to the proliferation of tumor cells, stimulation of osteoclasts that destroy the bone, and inhibition of osteoblast cells that form new bone resulting in osteolytic lesions. Recurrent infections in multiple myeloma are due to hypogammaglobulinemia. Hypercalcemia results from the chronic mobilization of calcium from bones.

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder: (specifically CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance of <40 mL/min or serum creatinine level of >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level >20 g/L (2 mg/dL) below the lowest limit of normal or hemoglobin level of <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron-emission tomography (PET)/CT
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on MRI that is at least 5 mm or greater in size

Option A - Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by multiple tiny, well-defined lucencies in the skull due to the resorption of trabecular bone, resulting in the salt and pepper appearance or pepper pot skull. The clinical features are mainly due to hypercalcemia and typically include anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, depression, fatigue, and muscle weakness. Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis can occur due to hypercalciuria. Joint symptoms occur due to chondrocalcinosis.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption of middle phalanges - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • An atypical cyst-like lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor 

Option C - Paget's disease is characterized by excessive bone remodeling. Most cases are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally on a radiograph or a raised alkaline phosphatase level. The symptoms include pain and deformities of the bones and cranial nerve palsy due to compression. The characteristic skull radiographic finding is the presence of mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull, which is referred to as the cotton wool appearance. 

Other radiographic findings in Paget's disease:

  • Picture frame vertebra
  • Squaring of vertebra on lateral radiographs
  • Blade of grass appearance in long bones

Option D- Eosinophilic granuloma is a mild form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis and is characterized by abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells, with an abundance of eosinophils, neutrophils, and lymphocytes. It results in medullary bone resorption. It usually presents with pain and swelling in the affected area. Otitis media and mastoiditis occur if the calvarium is involved. Compression fractures and neurological symptoms occur in spinal involvement. The characteristic skull finding is the geographic skull and solitary or multiple lytic lesions, with a beveled-edge appearance.

Other radiographic findings in eosinophilic granuloma:

  • Vertebra plana
  • Floating tooth in the mandible

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: The condition is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
The above radiologicalimage shows a short 4th metacarpal.

Causes of short 4th metacarpal:

  • Pseudohypoparathyroidism
  • Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism
  • Turner’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic
  • Post infection

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes with a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability. The ultrasound image of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability along with ultrasound findings of double decidual sign points to the diagnosis of normal pregnancy.

This sign can be seen in first-trimester transvaginal sonograms. In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that are - the outer decidua parietalis and the inner decidua capsularis. The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac. The presence of the yolk sac confirms the intrauterine location of the pregnancy. It usually appears by the 5th week.

Another indicator of early intrauterine pregnancy is the intradecidual sign. It is seen as an anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim.

Cardiac motion is usually seen after the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A patient who is known to have pulmonary adenocarcinoma presents with severe dyspnea. A chest X-ray was taken which reveals the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of dyspnoea and chest X-ray findings suggests a diagnosis of massive pleural effusion  

The chest X-ray above shows a massive left-sided pleural effusion that is displacing the heart and trachea to the right. 

Pleural effusion is the abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity. It can be seen on chest X-rays as homogenous opacification of the lower chest as well as the blunting of the lateral costophrenic angle and hemidiaphragm. If pleural effusion can be seen to the level of the fourth anterior rib, it means that a fluid volume of around 1000mL would be present. A massive pleural effusion would cause a mediastinal shift to the opposite side and an opacification of the hemithorax. 

Other options:

Option A: Consolidation is the filling of alveolar spaces with fluid. If it is fairly dense, it can be easily localized. It can be seen in community-acquired pneumonia. The X-ray shown below shows a consolidation within the right mid and both lower lobes.  

 

Option B: Pneumatoceles are shaggy thin-walled cavities that are seen on chest X-ray. Pneumatoceles can be seen in respiratory tract infections and are most often caused by S. aureus in children and P. jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. It is shown below.

 

Option C: Pneumothorax is air in the pleural space that is often caused by trauma. It can be seen in the chest X-ray as an area void of lung vascularity and a thin white line of visceral pleura that is separated from the parietal pleura by air.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the Bagel sign on sonography as shown below?
questions.solution:
Bagel sign on an ultrasonogram (USG) is seen in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Bagel sign is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Other options:

Option C: Double decidual sac sign is seen on USG in early intrauterine pregnancy. It is seen ​​as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac (image below).

 

Option D: Spalding sign is seen on USG in intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD). It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another (image below).

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI image given above is FLAIR.

  • In FLAIR images CSF and white matter is dark.
  • FLAIR (fluid attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid.

In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark whereas in T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white.

STIR (Short tau inversion recovery) is done to detect bone marrow oedema.

Here White matter appears darker than gray while gray matter appears gray and the fluids appear very bright.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

Structure
T1 image
T2 image
Grey matter
Darker
 Lighter
White matter
 Lighter  Darker
CSF/ Fluids
Dark
Bright
Fat
White
Less white
Air
Dark
Dark
Cortical bone
Dark
Dark
Tendons and ligaments
Dark
Dark
Calcification
 Variable
Dark
Flowing blood and hemosiderin
Dark
Dark

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with parkinsonism and cerebellar features. The MRI of this patient shows the following findings over the pons. Identify the sign shown in the image.

MRI - Magnetic resonance imaging
questions.solution:
The given MRI image shows pontine hot cross bun sign seen in patients with multiple system atrophy (MSA) with predominant cerebellar features

MSA manifests as a combination of parkinsonian, cerebellar, and autonomic features. Based on predominant clinical features it is further divided into :

  • MSA-P: predominantly parkinsonian features
  • MSA-C: predominantly cerebellar features

Characteristic MRI findings include:

  • MSA-P: T2 weighted imaging demonstrates hyperintense putaminal rim 
  • MSA-C: cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

Below image shows hot cross bun sign (arrow) due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy.

Other options:

Option B: Molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles gives the midbrain the appearance of a molar or wisdom tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome.

Option C: The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients with Sturge-Weber Syndrome.

Option D: Dawson's fingers are multiple FLAIR hyperintense lesions arranged perpendicular to the lateral ventricles in a triangular configuration which is typical for multiple sclerosis.
